Award.AwardTitle: Development of a classroom observation format and protocol to assess student participation and interactivity in undergraduate STEM courses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In higher education, classroom observations are typically conducted to review and evaluate an instructor's performance. There are two main problems with this approach. First, different observers have their own ideas of what constitutes "good teaching," and often rely on these personal standards in their judgments. Thus, in principle, different observers will review the same class differently. Worse, the evaluation provides suboptimal feedback to the observed instructors because it is not typically based on evidence-based methods linked to positive student outcomes.

The focus of this project is the testing of an evaluative observation tool that is more object and informative than traditional methods. This work in progress is known as the Student Participation Observation Tool (SPOT). It is being designed as a computerized observing format and protocol that will allow an observer to categorize classroom actions during an observation, resulting in detailed time-stamped information about the progression of the class. SPOT is being designed to capture data about the use of teaching practices that promote positive student outcomes, in order to be useful to both evaluators and instructors. As a design consideration, SPOT will be easy to use and therefore will have potential for widespread adoption among faculty developers and others who routinely conduct classroom observations. This exploratory project integrates research and design components to 1) develop the observation tool based on a series of design goals, and 2) evaluate the effectiveness of the tool (how well it meets the design goals). The design objective is drawing on education research and existing observation tools to develop a format and protocol that allows collecting real-time data about student and teacher behaviors that are linked to positive student learning outcomes.

The evaluation objective is to assess the usability and usefulness of the observation format and protocol to provide valid and reliable data to instructors and evaluators about classroom practices so that they may make evidence-based decisions regarding STEM education. SPOT is being developed based on a similar well-tested tool that categorizes classroom behaviors in real time. The protocol is being developed based on a review of K-12 literature and discipline-specific higher education research regarding instructor and student classroom behaviors that result in positive student outcomes. Subsequent field-testing of SPOT in a wide-range of courses at San Jose State University will be undertaken to improve usability, and establish the validity and reliability of the tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In higher education, classroom observations are traditionally conducted to review and evaluate the instructor’s performance. There are two main problems with traditional means of conducting classroom observations. First, different observers have their own ideas of what constitutes "good teaching," and thus will review the same class differently. Second, the evaluation provides minimal useful feedback to faculty, and little if any of this feedback is based on evidence-based methods linked to positive student outcomes.The main deliverable of this project is an observation tool that is less subjective and more informative than methods traditionally used to observe and evaluate STEM faculty. The Student Participation Observation Tool (SPOT), is a computer-based application and protocol, founded in evidence-based science teaching practices that allows an observer to categorize classroom actions during an observation, resulting in detailed time-stamped information about the progression of the class.

Specifically, SPOT captures data regarding the use of teaching practices, like asking questions and providing student wait-time, that promote positive student outcomes. SPOT allows an observer to click buttons that represent instructor and student actions in the classroom, and instantly creates charts and graphs that instructors can use to understand how time is spent in their class. They have information about both the types of actions that take place, and the diversity of participation in their classroom. Furthermore, SPOT is easy to use and therefore has the potential for widespread adoption among faculty developers and others who routinely conduct classroom observations.

With the funding provided by this grant we were able to 1) conduct a survey of the literature to determine which observable classroom teaching practices are linked to positive student learning outcomes, 2) design and create SPOT, which is available for public use at sjsuspot.appspot.com, 3) facilitate a SPOT workshop series which also provided a means to investigate how faculty use SPOT to reflect on their teaching, and 4) collect preliminary data on how faculty felt SPOT might fit into the instructor evaluation process in higher education.

Our research with faculty using SPOT shows that this tool provided  instructors with information about their practice that they didn't already know. For example, some users were surprised by how little time they allowed for student voices in the classroom, and others realized that much of the classroom participation was limited to a small fraction of the students enrolled in the class. Many of the faculty made changes to their classrooms based on the data that we collected with SPOT. All of the faculty in the study indicated that SPOT would be a positive addition to the faculty retention and promotion process, but cautioned that it should be used with other teaching evidence, which the researchers agree with.

By integrating teaching feedback with routine faculty evaluations, SPOT allows faculty to easily examine how they are using effective practices, as determined by education research. This research has the potential to result in more widespread adoption of student-centered active-learning practices, and thus, lead to improved student learning outcomes in undergraduate STEM courses.
